label: Letter from John Cox to Nathanael Greene
description: Letter from John Cox to Nathanael Greene reporting an encounter between 800 Continental troops, North Carolina militia, Virginia militia, and the British. Cox reports that the American troops were outnumbered and eventually defeated by Lord Cornwallis and his men.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
[John Cox to Nathanael Greene
September 2, 1780
[RvW Box 2 Folder 40; MSS. – A.L.S.]]

Bloomsbury Septr [September] 2d. 1780
Dear Sir
The Day before yesterday an aid of General
Gates's [sic] arrived in Philada. with dispatches to Congress,
containging [sic] the following disagreeable Intelligence.
That on the 16th. Ultio at daylight Lord Cornwallis with
1,800 British, [and] about 1200 Refugees [and]c. attacked General
Gates's Army compound of about 800 Continental Troops,
the North Carolina militia, under the command of
General Caswell, Brig.r Rutherford [and] [?] [and] the Virginia
militia under General Stephens. The Enemy first
made an attack with their Horn, amounting in
numbers to abt 400. Our whole force of Calvary not
exceeding 100 under the command of Col. [Colonel] Armand –
The orders given by Gl.. Gates to the Troops were not
to discharge their pieces till they were close to the
Enemy, [and] then to give one fire [and] charge with 
fixed Bayonets, which was bravely [and] Heroically done by
Guist [Mordecai Gist] [and] his Troops. The Virginia Militia then advanced
a little, the Carolinians gave way, [and] broke totally, very soon
after which the Virginia militia followed their example.
[End Page 1]
General Smallwood then advanced, [and] endeavoured [sic] to rally
them, but to no effect.  he then took the ground that
the Virginians had retreated from, [and] charged the Enemy
with the greatest imaginable Bravery, but their Horses
pouring in thro the great interval left by the
Militia, furiously attacked Green [and] Smallwood in the
Rear, while the Infantry attacked them in front, which
induces a belief that most of our brave fellows have
fallen. General Smallwood [and] a considerable number of
Field officers are killed. no particular account of Genl. [General]
Guists fate, tho it is to be feared that he will mist [sic]
of the brave fellows that surrounded him full fighting.
All our Baggages, Tents, Ammunition, Waggons [and] 
Artillery, being Eight field pieces, are taken. Col
Armand [and] his whole Corps cut to pieces, in short there
is a total [and] dreadful defeat of our Army. Genl
Gates [and] Baron de Keaub [de Kalb] endeavoured to Rally the
Militias but to no purpose. a part of the Enemys
horse pursued General Gates [and] the Baron 25 miles from
the seat of action, which prevented their returning
to the field, by which means we all left entirely
in
[End Page 2]
the dark as to the particulars of killed, wounded,
[and] Prisoners, but from the bravery of our Troops,
[and] the situation they were left in, it is to be
feared that great numbers have fallen –
Genl Gates [and] the Baron are at Hilsbury – Genl Caswell
escaped, [and] is exerting himself –
We had a body of  8 or 900 men about 12 miles
from the field of action on the other side of the
river, which woud have joined Genl. [General] Gates in a Day
or two at farthest – had the Militia behaved
well it is not doubted but we shoud have kept
the field – Genl Guist at first drove the Enemy –
The action was abt 8 miles this side Cambden
G. Gates took up his march at 10 O'clock at night
of the 15th in order to possess himself of a piece
of advantageous ground, not expecting that the
Enemy had received their reinforcedment from
Charles Town, which arrived the night before [and]
Lord Cornwallis on his march to attack Gates in
his Camp the Armies met about 2 O Clock in
the morning, we had rather the highest ground,
but
[End Page 3]
their great superiority of Horse as well as Infantry
soon gave us a fated overthrow – The foregoing
particulars I this moment Received, [and] have given them to
you hastily the Post being just ready to mount.
I am with Respect [and]
Dear Sir
Your Aft [and] Obdt [Obedient]
Hble [Humble] Servant
John Cox -
[Endorsed on right margin:] From Colonel Cox
Sepr. 2d. 1780.
-  72  -
Gates's defeat
[Addressed upside down:] Genl. [General] Greene -
[End Page 4]
